I am a burn survivor, not a victim. But at age 16, due to a horrific car accident, I was burned very badly from head to toe. Before the accident, I was like you. I loved to build things, make inventions and work with my hands... The fire took all that away from me. As such, I don't have any fingers in my left hand and the right hand is useless. It would be great if you were able to make some sort of robotic hand that would go over the hand with no fingers because the Drs won't amputate the hand off because even though I don't have fingers, just nubs. I have part of my thumb left which gives me about an inch of space in which to grab stuff. Congrats on the 10 Million, and I'm so glad to hear that you plan to keep pushing and to use your platform to try and bring more good into the world. You mentioned a comment about how there are always naysayers about the projects just done for "the luls" or that doesn't have a direct benefit. But a comment from Neil DeGrasse Tyson always rings in my head when people bring this up. He mentions that his Grad School Supervisor, also an Astro-physicist, published a now well known article about using magnetism in the study of space and Astro-Physics applications. This paper had no overt benefit, and in fact to this day the research itself isn't extremely beneficial beyond the study of space. However, someone read this article, and using the principals in the article he invented the MRI or Magnetic Resonance Imaging system, which is one of the most significant Medical tools used today. In short, any step forward, no matter how inconsequential it may seem is a step forward that may lead someone else to take even greater leaps. thus, all research and exploration is important, not just that which we see a direct benefit to us before hand. I hope that you continue to inspire people and grow as you currently hope to, I will stay here, eagerly awaiting each advancement, and hope for the day when I can have my own lightsaber at my side XD. Stay well, and take care of yourself.

I know you won't see this most likely, but I just want to say, in regards to the negative comments and the criticism: I know it's hard, but just take the good and leave the bad. Understand what they are actually trying to tell you, and separate that from their emotion. There's a lot of broken, underdeveloped, messed up people, that are not in a good place. It's not like those nasty comments are coming from someone like you. It's just messed up people punching up because they don't feel like what they say matters anyways. So when you understand how broken someone is, it's a lot harder to take their criticism personally. So that's my advice, keep that wider perspective, it will help you to both understand people and to not be hurt by what they say.

Product development is a big step up from prototypes.. maybe 25% of it is actual engineering. The rest is project management, market research, regulatory compliance, sales, marketing, documentation, verification/validation, business development, supplier contracts etc etc.  I do hope you get there and it works out for you :-) probably the most important thing to remember is that not everyone might think your invention is as useful as you do. The hardest part of being an innovator/inventor is knowing which idea to put your effort into.. and its often not the coolest or most interesting one.  Anyway, I've enjoyed your videos for many years, so I'd like to give something back.. if you ever need help/advice on the product design front let me know, I'll drop you a contact email on your website. I've spent nearly 25 years developing Electronics for optical devices, robotic systems, sensors, medical, as well as founding a successful start-up company.  Best of luck James & Co :-)  Malc

3D printing has changed my life forever in a good way. The things I have done for people by printing something  for them seeing there faces is pricesless. I recently 3D printed builder plates of two steam locomotives for a 96 year old man. He used run those two engines of which plates I printed for him. I did them for free, I do not know him but when I seen his picture of him running the engines I knew at that moment that I wanted to make those plates for him. I received a picture of him holding the plates I made for him with a huge smile. That felt so good to do that for him. It's not about the money, becoming famous or any of that. It's what a person can do something that they love to do and change peoples life. And don't listen to what people say, I learned that quickly. Your videos do inspire me.
